title: Obadiah Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Obadiah chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Obadiah Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Obadiah Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is the vision in Obadiah 1:1 concerning?
questions.correctAnswer: Edom
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:1 states that the vision is concerning Edom.

questions.question: According to Obadiah 1:2, how is Edom described among the heathen?
questions.correctAnswer: Small and greatly despised
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:2 says Edom is made small among the heathen and is greatly despised.

questions.question: What does Edom boast in his heart according to Obadiah 1:3?
options: Who shall bring me down to the ground?
questions.correctAnswer: Who shall bring me down to the ground?
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:3 says Edom says in his heart, 'Who shall bring me down to the ground?'

questions.question: True or False: Obadiah 1:4 says that though Edom sets his nest among the stars, the LORD will bring him down.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:4 states that even if Edom exalts himself as the eagle and sets his nest among the stars, the LORD will bring him down.

questions.question: In Obadiah 1:5, what is said about thieves and robbers coming to Edom?
options: They would steal only a little
They would steal until they had enough
They would be stopped by Edom
questions.correctAnswer: They would steal until they had enough
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:5 says if thieves or robbers came, they would have stolen until they had enough.

questions.question: According to Obadiah 1:7, who has deceived Edom?
questions.correctAnswer: The men of his confederacy
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:7 states that the men of Edom's confederacy have deceived and prevailed against him.

questions.question: What will happen to the wise men of Edom according to Obadiah 1:8?
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:8 says the LORD will destroy the wise men out of Edom.

questions.question: True or False: Obadiah 1:10 says Edom will be rewarded for their kindness to Jacob.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:10 declares that because of Edom's violence against Jacob, shame shall cover Edom and they shall be cut off forever.

questions.question: What did Edom do on the day strangers carried away captive Jacob's forces, according to Obadiah 1:11?
options: Stood on the other side as one of them
questions.correctAnswer: Stood on the other side as one of them
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:11 states Edom stood on the other side and was as one of the strangers carrying away captive Jacob's forces.

questions.question: According to Obadiah 1:12, what should Edom not have done during Judah's destruction?
options: Rejoiced over the children of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoiced over the children of Judah
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:12 says Edom should not have rejoiced over the children of Judah in the day of their destruction.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Obadiah 1:15 says, 'For the day of the LORD is near upon all the ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: heathen
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:15 states the day of the LORD is near upon all the heathen.

questions.question: What will happen to all the heathen according to Obadiah 1:16?
options: They shall drink continually and be as though they had not been
questions.correctAnswer: They shall drink continually and be as though they had not been
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:16 describes that all the heathen shall drink continually and be as though they had not been.

questions.question: True or False: Obadiah 1:17 promises deliverance upon Mount Zion.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:17 states that upon Mount Zion shall be deliverance, holiness, and possession for the house of Jacob.

questions.question: According to Obadiah 1:18, the house of Esau will be like what?
questions.correctAnswer: Stubble
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:18 compares the house of Esau to stubble that will be kindled and devoured.

questions.question: Which group is said to possess the mount of Esau according to Obadiah 1:19?
questions.correctAnswer: The children of the south
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:19 states that those of the south shall possess the mount of Esau.

medium.title: Obadiah Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Obadiah Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and self-reliance. Based on Obadiah 1, what biblical truth would you share about humility?
options: Pride leads to downfall because God humbles the arrogant
Pride is a strength that protects us from enemies
Self-reliance without God is always blessed
Pride is acceptable if it protects your family
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall because God humbles the arrogant
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:3-4 teaches that pride deceives and that even if one exalts themselves as the eagle, God will bring them down. This shows the importance of humility before God.

questions.question: How does Obadiah 1 teach us about trusting God rather than our own strength in difficult times?
options: God will bring down those who trust in their own fortified places
Strength alone guarantees victory over enemies
Trusting in physical protection is sufficient
One should depend on alliances for safety
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring down those who trust in their own fortified places
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 4 describe how Edom trusted in their high rocky dwelling and pride but God declares He will bring them down, emphasizing trust in God over human strength.

questions.question: A believer faces betrayal by friends. According to Obadiah 1, what principle can encourage them to maintain integrity?
options: Those who deceive will ultimately be judged by God
Betrayal is common and should be expected without consequence
Trust should be given only to family members
questions.correctAnswer: Those who deceive will ultimately be judged by God
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:7 explains how those who were at peace with Edom betrayed and prevailed against them, and verses 8-9 show that God will destroy the wise and mighty of Edom, affirming divine justice.

questions.question: What does Obadiah 1 teach about how we should respond to the suffering of others, especially believers?
options: We should not rejoice or exploit their distress
It is acceptable to take advantage when others suffer
Pride allows us to stand apart and remain unaffected
questions.correctAnswer: We should not rejoice or exploit their distress
questions.explanation: Verses 11-14 strongly condemn Edom for standing aloof, rejoicing, and exploiting Judah’s calamity, teaching believers to show compassion and not to harm those in distress.

questions.question: How does Obadiah 1 encourage believers to practice forgiveness and reconciliation?
options: We should not rejoice in the downfall of others but seek peace
Holding grudges is justified when wronged
Revenge is the best way to honor God
Ignoring offenses is the best path
questions.correctAnswer: We should not rejoice in the downfall of others but seek peace
questions.explanation: The rebuke in verses 12-14 against rejoicing over a brother’s destruction implies believers should avoid bitterness and instead pursue reconciliation and peace.

questions.question: A Christian is tempted to exploit another's misfortune for gain. What biblical warning from Obadiah 1 would you share?
options: Exploiting others in distress leads to judgment and recompense
It is wise to take advantage when opportunity arises
God favors those who gain wealth at any cost
questions.correctAnswer: Exploiting others in distress leads to judgment and recompense
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:13-15 warn that exploiting the calamity of others results in God's judgment returning upon the offender, emphasizing integrity and compassion.

questions.question: What does Obadiah 1 reveal about God's justice and the principle of 'reaping what you sow'?
options: The day of the LORD brings judgment corresponding to one's actions
God overlooks the deeds of the nations
questions.correctAnswer: The day of the LORD brings judgment corresponding to one's actions
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states that as Edom has done, so it shall be done to them, showing the biblical principle of just recompense based on actions.

questions.question: How can Obadiah 1 guide believers in remaining content and grateful amid trials?
options: Trusting God's deliverance and ultimate justice brings peace
Focus on personal strength to overcome
Rejoice in the misfortune of others for comfort
Ignore trials as they will pass on their own
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God's deliverance and ultimate justice brings peace
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 promise deliverance upon Mount Zion and holiness, encouraging believers to trust God's justice rather than envy or bitterness.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the apparent success of the wicked. What hope does Obadiah 1 provide?
options: The house of Jacob will prevail and consume the wicked as fuel
The wicked will always prosper without consequence
God does not intervene in earthly affairs
Success is determined by human effort alone
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Jacob will prevail and consume the wicked as fuel
questions.explanation: Verse 18 depicts the house of Jacob as a fire consuming the house of Esau, symbolizing God's ultimate victory over evil.

questions.question: How does Obadiah 1 encourage believers to live with integrity and honesty in their work and relationships?
options: Exploiting others' misfortune will bring ruin, so live honestly
Dishonesty is a necessary evil for success
Only the strong survive by any means
questions.correctAnswer: Exploiting others' misfortune will bring ruin, so live honestly
questions.explanation: Verses 13-15 warn against taking advantage of others in distress and show that God’s judgment falls on those who act unjustly.

questions.question: True or False: According to Obadiah 1, God values and rewards faithfulness and holiness in His people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 17 affirms that upon Mount Zion there will be deliverance and holiness, indicating God’s blessing on faithfulness and holiness.

questions.question: True or False: Obadiah 1 teaches that God will completely destroy those who act violently against His people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 and 18 show that God will destroy the wise and mighty men of Edom and that the house of Esau will be consumed, demonstrating divine judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Obadiah 1:10 says, 'For thy ___________ against thy brother Jacob shame shall cover thee, and thou shalt be cut off for ever.'
questions.correctAnswer: violence
questions.explanation: Verse 10 specifically states 'For thy violence against thy brother Jacob shame shall cover thee,' indicating that violence against others brings shame and judgment.

questions.question: How does Obadiah 1 guide believers in their witness and evangelism regarding justice and mercy?
options: God’s justice will prevail, so we must show mercy and avoid exploitation
Justice and mercy are unrelated to evangelism
Evangelism requires strict judgment without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice will prevail, so we must show mercy and avoid exploitation
questions.explanation: The passage highlights God's judgment on those who exploit others (verses 11-15) and the promise of deliverance for the righteous (verses 17-18), encouraging mercy alongside justice.

questions.question: Based on Obadiah 1, what encouragement can you give a believer who is persevering through trials caused by others' betrayal?
options: God will bring justice and deliverance to those who remain faithful
Betrayal means God has abandoned you
Retaliate against those who harm you
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring justice and deliverance to those who remain faithful
questions.explanation: Verses 17-21 promise deliverance for Mount Zion and judgment against Edom, encouraging perseverance and trust in God's justice.

hard.title: Obadiah Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Obadiah Chapter 1.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for Edom's downfall according to Obadiah 1?
options: Their pride and violence against Jacob
questions.correctAnswer: Their pride and violence against Jacob
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:3-4 and 10 emphasize Edom's pride and violence against their brother Jacob as the cause of their judgment.

questions.question: Which metaphor is used in Obadiah 1 to describe Edom's lofty but doomed position?
options: An eagle setting its nest among the stars
A lion roaring on the mountain
questions.correctAnswer: An eagle setting its nest among the stars
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:4 uses the metaphor of an eagle exalting itself and setting its nest among the stars, symbolizing pride and lofty security that will be brought down.

questions.question: According to Obadiah 1, what will happen to the wise men and mighty men of Edom?
options: They will be destroyed and dismayed
They will lead a victorious army
They will negotiate peace with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed and dismayed
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:8-9 states that the wise men will be destroyed and the mighty men will be dismayed, leading to the slaughter of Edom's people.

questions.question: In Obadiah 1, what does Edom’s behavior during Jerusalem’s captivity reveal?
options: They rejoiced and acted as enemies
They offered refuge to the captives
They sent aid to rebuild Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: They rejoiced and acted as enemies
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:11-14 condemns Edom for standing aloof, rejoicing over Judah’s destruction and even delivering up those who escaped.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'thy reward shall return upon thine own head' in Obadiah 1:15 signify in a biblical justice context?
options: Retributive justice according to one’s own deeds
A call for repentance and mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Retributive justice according to one’s own deeds
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:15 expresses the principle of lex talionis, where Edom’s actions against others will be reciprocated upon themselves.

questions.question: How does Obadiah 1 use the imagery of drinking on the holy mountain (verse 16) in relation to Edom and the nations?
options: To symbolize judgment and downfall for all nations
To illustrate a joyful feast of peace
To describe a ritual of purification
questions.correctAnswer: To symbolize judgment and downfall for all nations
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:16 uses the imagery of drinking on God’s holy mountain as a metaphor for the nations’ judgment and destruction.

questions.question: What does the contrast between the house of Jacob and the house of Esau in Obadiah 1:18 symbolize in the broader biblical narrative?
options: The triumph of God’s chosen people over their enemies
The merging of two tribes into one
questions.correctAnswer: The triumph of God’s chosen people over their enemies
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:18 symbolically contrasts the victorious house of Jacob with the house of Esau consumed like stubble, reflecting longstanding biblical themes of divine election and judgment.

questions.question: Which geographic locations are mentioned in Obadiah 1 as areas to be possessed by the children of Israel after Edom’s downfall?
options: Mount Esau, fields of Ephraim, Samaria, Gilead
The Nile Delta, Damascus, Edom, Moab
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Esau, fields of Ephraim, Samaria, Gilead
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:19-20 lists these locations as possessions of the southern tribes and Israel after Edom’s defeat.

questions.question: True or False: Obadiah 1 accuses Edom of helping foreigners carry away Jerusalem’s forces in captivity.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:11 states that Edom stood by as foreigners took Jerusalem’s forces captive and even acted as one of them.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Obadiah 1:18 when contrasting the house of Jacob with the house of Esau?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:18 employs parallelism contrasting Jacob as fire and Joseph as flame with Esau as stubble, a common Hebrew poetic device.

questions.question: How does the prophecy in Obadiah 1 reflect the historical tension between Edom and Israel?
options: It condemns Edom for betraying Israel during their calamity
It praises Edom for their loyalty to Israel
It calls for Edom to be Israel’s ally against Moab
It predicts Edom’s alliance with Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: It condemns Edom for betraying Israel during their calamity
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:11-14 condemns Edom for acting hostilely instead of supporting their brother nation during captivity.

questions.question: Which phrase in Obadiah 1 indicates that Edom’s pride was self-deceptive?
options: "The pride of thine heart hath deceived thee"
"Behold, I have made thee small among the heathen"
"How are the things of Esau searched out"
"For the day of the LORD is near upon all the heathen"
questions.correctAnswer: "The pride of thine heart hath deceived thee"
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:3 directly states that Edom’s pride deceived them, highlighting their false sense of invincibility.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Obadiah 1:7, those who were at peace with Edom "have laid a wound under thee" and "there is none ______ in him."
questions.correctAnswer: understanding
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:7 says there is none understanding in him, highlighting betrayal by supposed allies.

questions.question: What is the ultimate fate of the house of Esau as prophesied in Obadiah 1?
options: They will be completely consumed and have no survivors
They will be restored and become a great nation
They will form a lasting alliance with Judah
questions.correctAnswer: They will be completely consumed and have no survivors
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:18 clearly states there will not be any remaining of the house of Esau.

questions.question: According to Obadiah 1, who will come up on Mount Zion to judge the mount of Esau?
questions.correctAnswer: Saviours
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:21 declares that saviours will come up on Mount Zion to judge Edom.

theological.title: Obadiah Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Obadiah Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for Edom's judgment as described in Obadiah 1?
questions.correctAnswer: Violence against his brother Jacob
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:10 explicitly states that Edom's violence against his brother Jacob brings shame and eternal cut-off. This reflects God's condemnation of fraternal violence as seen also in Genesis 27:41, Psalm 137:7, and Luke 14:26.

questions.question: According to Obadiah 1, how does the LORD describe the pride of Edom?
questions.correctAnswer: Deceptive and self-exalting
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:3 warns that the pride of Edom's heart deceives them, dwelling in high places and arrogantly questioning who can bring them down. This is consistent with Isaiah 14:13-14 and Proverbs 16:18 about pride leading to downfall.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Obadiah 1 to describe Edom's futile attempt to exalt itself?
options: An eagle setting its nest among the stars
A lion ruling over the forest
A tree planted by the rivers of water
questions.correctAnswer: An eagle setting its nest among the stars
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:4 uses the image of an eagle exalting itself and setting its nest among the stars, yet God will bring it down. This imagery parallels Isaiah 40:31 and Daniel 7:4 where the eagle represents pride and impending judgment.

questions.question: How does Obadiah 1 depict the relationship between Edom and those who were at peace with it?
options: They were unaware of Edom's plight
questions.correctAnswer: They deceived and betrayed Edom
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:7 states that those at peace with Edom deceived and prevailed against it, laying a wound under it. This highlights the theme of betrayal reminiscent of Psalm 41:9 and John 13:18 where betrayal comes from close associates.

questions.question: What eschatological theme is prominent in Obadiah 1:15?
options: The day of the LORD bringing judgment upon all nations
The outpouring of the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: The day of the LORD bringing judgment upon all nations
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:15 proclaims that the day of the LORD is near upon all heathen, with recompense returning to each according to their deeds. This aligns with Joel 2:31, Acts 2:20, and Revelation 6:17 regarding divine eschatological judgment.

questions.question: What promise is made concerning Mount Zion in Obadiah 1?
options: Deliverance and holiness will be established there
It will be destroyed by the nations
It will be given to the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Deliverance and holiness will be established there
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:17 declares that upon Mount Zion there shall be deliverance and holiness, and Jacob shall possess his possessions. This fits the biblical motif of Zion as the place of God's salvation (Psalm 48:2, Isaiah 2:3, Hebrews 12:22).

questions.question: What does Obadiah 1:18 symbolize by describing the house of Jacob as a fire and the house of Esau as stubble?
options: Jacob's enduring power and Esau's destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob's enduring power and Esau's destruction
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:18 uses fire and stubble imagery to show Jacob's consuming power and Esau's vulnerability, reflecting God's judgment. Similar symbolism appears in Isaiah 10:17 and Malachi 4:1 regarding God's refining fire and judgment.

questions.question: Which group is described as coming up on Mount Zion to judge the mount of Esau in Obadiah 1?
questions.correctAnswer: Saviours
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:21 foretells that saviours shall come up on Mount Zion to judge Esau's mount, indicating divine agents executing God's justice. This has eschatological resonance with Isaiah 59:20 and Romans 11:26 about the coming of the Redeemer and judgment.

questions.question: What does Obadiah 1:11 accuse Edom of doing during the captivity of Judah?
options: Standing aloof and acting as an enemy
Refusing to participate in the captivity
questions.correctAnswer: Standing aloof and acting as an enemy
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:11 condemns Edom for standing on the other side when Judah was captive and even casting lots on Jerusalem, acting as if one of the enemies. This echoes Psalm 137:7 and Lamentations 4:21 where Edom's hostility is condemned.

questions.question: According to Obadiah 1, what will happen to the possessions of those who afflicted Jacob in the day of their calamity?
options: They will be taken away and possessed by Jacob
They will remain with the oppressors
They will be destroyed by fire
They will be given to the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: They will be taken away and possessed by Jacob
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:13-14 states that Edom should not have taken possessions during Judah's calamity, and later verses (19-20) show that the fields and cities taken will be possessed by others, including Jacob's descendants. This aligns with Exodus 15:9 and Isaiah 61:4 on restoration.

questions.question: How does Obadiah 1 portray the wisdom and understanding of Edom's leaders in the day of judgment?
options: They will be destroyed and removed
They will be exalted and honored
They will lead a great revival
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed and removed
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:8 declares that God will destroy the wise men and understanding from Edom, symbolizing divine judgment that removes leadership as also seen in Jeremiah 51:57 and Ezekiel 28:8.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'thy reward shall return upon thine own head' in Obadiah 1:15 indicate about God's justice?
options: Retributive justice where one receives according to their deeds
questions.correctAnswer: Retributive justice where one receives according to their deeds
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:15 emphasizes that God’s judgment is retributive, reflecting the principle of sowing and reaping found in Proverbs 11:31, Galatians 6:7, and Romans 2:6.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the tone of Obadiah 1 concerning Edom's future?
questions.correctAnswer: Certain destruction and eradication
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:18 and 9 describe the total destruction of Edom’s mighty men and house, with no survivors, emphasizing God's sovereign judgment consistent with Ezekiel 25:12-14 and Malachi 1:4.

questions.question: What role do the 'heathen' or Gentile nations play in Obadiah 1's prophecy?
options: They will be judged for their deeds
They will inherit the promises without judgment
They remain neutral in God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: They will be judged for their deeds
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1:15-16 reveals that all heathen will face God's judgment according to their actions, consistent with Romans 1:18, Matthew 25:32-46, and Revelation 20:12.

questions.question: How does Obadiah 1 illustrate God's attribute of sovereignty over nations?
options: By declaring Edom's downfall and the restoration of Israel
By allowing nations to act independently without consequence
By remaining silent about the nations
questions.correctAnswer: By declaring Edom's downfall and the restoration of Israel
questions.explanation: Obadiah 1 demonstrates God's sovereign control in ordaining Edom's destruction and Israel's restoration (verses 17-21), a theme echoed in Daniel 4:35, Psalm 22:28, and Isaiah 46:9-10.
